block.p: Governing Party in Japan Suffers Election Setback Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party suffered a dramatic setback in parliamentary elections. The party barely retained control over the powerful lower house in a surprisingly weak showing that could put strong pressure on its recently appointed prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, to resign.

Monitors Criticize Zimbabwe European Union observers, in their first report on Zimbabwe's elections, condemned the governing party, saying it had supported a campaign of violence before the vote and had obstructed the work of local election monitors.

Apartheid Party Dissolved The party that created apartheid in South Africa decided to dissolve and merge with a rival party to create a new entity that is likely to attract most of that country's white, Indian and mixed-race voters.

Russia Pullback on Chechnya The Russian military, in a move clearly intended to build support for Moscow's newly appointed administrator of Chechnya, declared that it had suspended air strikes and artillery attacks in the region.

Muted Ceremonies in Seoul President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea, in a muted ceremony commemorating the outbreak of war on the Korean peninsula 50 years ago, paid tribute to the soldiers who fought and died in the conflict.

Leading Conservative in Canada Stockwell Day, a flat-tax advocate and former treasurer of Alberta, has emerged as the front-runner in the race to lead Canada's new conservative party, winning 44 percent of votes in a four-way leadership primary. The winner of a July 8 runoff will try to wrest control from the Liberals.
Barak Condemns Arson Attack Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel condemned a fire that was set at a Conservative synagogue in Jerusalem as ''an awful act that causes every Jew to shudder.''

Iran Closes Liberal Newspaper A clerical court closed another of Iran's dwindling stock of liberal newspapers in a new challenge to the reformers who have promised to use their dominance in Parliament to repeal restrictive press laws.

Mexican Rejects Alliance Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, a leftist opposition presidential candidate, spurned an offer from the leading opposition contender, Vicente Fox Quesada, to make an alliance in hopes of defeating the Institutional Revolutionary Party. Supporters of the governing party candidate, Francisco Labastida Ochoa, rallied yesterday in Toluca.

Gore to Propose Incentives For Clean-Energy Products Vice President Al Gore will propose economic incentives to encourage cleaner technologies intended to reduce the nation's dependency on foreign oil. Mr. Gore's aides said he would call for billions of dollars in tax breaks and other federal subsidies to encourage consumers to buy clean-energy products, like solar houses, and to encourage companies to develop sources of energy that do not burn oil.

Lincoln's Cottage at Risk A country cottage where Abraham Lincoln spent almost a quarter of his incumbency and wrote a draft of the Emancipation Proclamation, is about to be designated by preservationists as the most endangered historic site in the nation.

Lab May Mislead on Security Officials at the Los Alamos National Laboratory have pressured employees to report that security at the laboratory is better than they actually believe, according to a new report by the Energy Department's inspector general.

Nader Leads the Green Ticket Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, accepted the presidential nomination of the Green Party with a blistering attack against Republicans, Democrats, Congress, corporate America and the commission that sets the rules for presidential debates.
Training Resumes on Vieques Military shelling returned to the island of Vieques, P.R., as the United States Navy began training, even while protesters vowed to invade the range.
Swimming Banned in Miami For the fifth straight day the beaches of Miami Beach were open only for sunbathing, in the wake of a huge sewage spill.

California Gains in Education California schools are getting some long overdue help with the state's budget now flush in a booming economy. In the past two years, the state has added about $7 billion for elementary and secondary education, an increase of about 20 percent, and has also begun ambitious programs to recruit and retain teachers with tax credits and home loans.

New York State to Sue Gun Makers and Dealers Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer plans to file suit against a raft of firearms makers and wholesalers, making New York the first state to take the industry to court, charging that it is partly responsible for the carnage from guns. The suit marks a significant escalation of the legal campaign that has been waged against the industry by 32 cities and counties around the country.

Paved-Over Park Reborn One of New York City's oldest and most elegant parks, which spent most of the 20th century as a parking lot for sanitation vehicles, is about to be reborn. The state recently agreed to provide about $1 million for a rebuilt park. The site is bordered by Canal and Washington Streets and the West Side Highway.

Three Drown Off Beaches A 6-year-old girl and her mother drowned and three other people were hospitalized after rip tides pushed them from Rockaway Beach in Queens more than 500 yards out into the Atlantic Ocean, the authorities said. In a separate accident, a teenager drowned in calm waters off Orchard Beach in the Bronx.

Concerns Over Toll Lines Vendors who use special toll lines from Bell Atlantic, offering information on obtaining jobs, apartments or dates, say the lines are useful. But others say the lines, particularly those marketed for residents of poor neighborhoods, are predatory.

Off-Duty Officer Is Shot An off-duty narcotics detective was shot in a furious, close-quarters gun battle with three men who tried to rob his family's laundry in Brooklyn, the authorities said. Two of the robbers were also injured, shot several times by the injured detective, Victor Romero, 36, as they ran. Mr. Romero was expected to survive.

Music Museum Opens in Seattle The Experience Music Project, the nation's second major rock museum, opened in Seattle in a building designed by Frank O. Gehry. The festivities included concerts by Eminem, Patti Smith and dozens of Northwest bands.

Inkster Wins L.P.G.A. Juli Inkster lost a three-stroke lead with five holes left in regulation, making a bogey on the final hole of regulation, to force her into a playoff against Stefania Croce in the McDonald's L.P.G.A. Championship. Inkster prevailed in sudden death.
Mets Sweep a Series Mike Hampton held the Pittsburgh Pirates to five hits, allowing only two after the second inning, as the New York Mets won, 9-0, and completed a sweep of the series.

Philip Morris to Buy Nabisco Philip Morris, the parent of Kraft Foods, announced that it would buy Nabisco Holdings, the food company that makes and markets Oreo cookies, Ritz Crackers, and other classic American packaged foods, in a $14.9 billion deal. The transaction would create the world's most profitable food company.

Blurring of Lines at CBS CBS will create further potential for blurring the lines between entertainment and news when the network kicks off its second reality series, ''Big Brother.'' A newscaster on ''The Early Show'' will present a weekly prime-time interview show based on developments in ''Big Brother'' and will also play the role of Big Brother on the program. ''The Early Show'' already covers the reality series ''Survivor.''

Internet Body Faces Lawsuit The Internet's administrative body, already low on cash and facing heavy criticism from international groups, has been served with what is believed to be the first lawsuit challenging its work. The suit was filed by a New York company denied entrance to the lucrative business of registering Internet addresses, or domain names.

Investing in Hyundai DaimlerChrysler said today that it would pay $428.9 million for a 10 percent stake in Hyundai Motor, South Korea's largest automaker. In a joint statement, the companies said they had agreed to an alliance that would include a joint venture to produce commercial vehicles.
Peter McWilliams The best-selling author of self-help books was 50. He gained attention in recent years by advocating, in print and in court, the legalization of marijuana.
Elsie Widdowson A nutritionist who used the discipline of wartime rationing to prescribe the healthiest diet in British history, she was 93.
